title: Correlation Analysis with R
text:
Build your problem-solving skills



For a data science team to build a good model, in-depth correlation analysis may be the best tool to consider.








Import Data



We need to import data needed for correlation analysis. In this case, we use data for Home Loan applicants to perform the analysis.




click here to view code
library(tidyverse)
data <- read_csv("./train.csv")%>%
  mutate_if(is.character, as_factor)%>%
  select(-Loan_ID)%>%
  mutate(Credit_History = as_factor(Credit_History))








A Quick Summary using skimr



You can perform a quick inspection of your data using skimr. This enables you to understand the overview of your data properties, shape, number of missing values, and descriptive summary.




click here to view code
library(skimr)
skim_without_charts(data)

A quick summary using DataExplorer








click here to view code
library(DataExplorer)
data%>%
  plot_missing(
    ggtheme = theme_classic(), 
    theme_config = list(legend.position = c("top")),
    title = "Missing value plot showing percentage of missing data points"
    )











A Quick Summary using dataxray








click here to view code
library(dataxray)
library(DT)
library(gt)
data%>%
  make_xray(by = 'Loan_Status')

# … with 12 more rows, 3 more variables: values_df <list>, extremes_df <list>,
#   spike_hist <list>, and abbreviated variable names ¹​Loan_Status, ²​distinct,
#   ³​counts_df








Correlation Analysis using correlationfunnel.



This section focused on the use of the correlationfunnel library to perform Correlation Analysis for the available data provided.




click here to view code
library(correlationfunnel)
data%>%
  na.omit()%>%
  binarize(n_bins = 5)%>%
  correlate(target = Loan_Status__Y)%>%
  plot_correlation_funnel(interactive = TRUE)

title: EDA using correlationfunnel
text:
Aggregate and visualize with correlalationfunnel





Loading the bike_orderlines dataset

bikes_tbl <- read_csv("./bike_orderlines.csv")%>%
  mutate_if(is.character, as_factor)%>%
  rename(category = category_1, sub_category = category_2)



Descriptive analysis with skimr
A general overview of the data

skimr::skim_without_charts(bikes_tbl)

Figure 1: Temperature and ozone level.



As we can see, our dataset have:

1 datetime variable,
7 categorical variables,
5 numeric variables.

Fortunately no missing values in the data. From the factor summary, shops from Kansas city contributed to the most bike sales which is from the Kansas State. Surprisingly, shops from Ithaca city have least bike sales which is from the NY state instead of AZ state as indicated on the summary. Elite road mountain bikes with carbon material have more bike sales. Trail road bikes with aluminium have the least number of bike sales.
Add more granular time variables (month, quarter & year)

sales <- bikes_tbl %>%
  mutate(month = month(order_date, abbr = FALSE,
                       label = TRUE,
                       locale = Sys.setlocale("LC_COLLATE", "C")),
         quarter = quarter(order_date),
         year = year(order_date))



2.3 Correlation of features

sales%>%
  select(-c(price, order_line, order_date, order_id))%>%
  binarize()%>%
  correlate(target = total_price__5330_Inf)%>%
  plot_correlation_funnel(interactive = TRUE, alpha = 5)





For a quick correlation analysis, we observe that bike model, frame material, quantity, category and sub category do significantly affect large sales volume.
